Situation1: The meeting will cover key project updates that won’t be summarized elsewhere.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: With only an hour left in the shift, they are still a few sales short of the weekly target.
Story: I glance at the clock on my computer screen—only an hour left in my shift. My heart pounds as I stare at the list of leads, knowing I’m still three sales short of my weekly target. Management has been clear: missing targets isn’t an option if I want to keep this job. I reach for the phone, but just then, a calendar reminder pops up. The team meeting is starting in five minutes. It’s not just any meeting; this one will cover key project updates that won’t be summarized later. My colleagues expect me to be there, to participate and show I’m part of the team. If I skip, I’ll let them down and risk missing out on crucial information. But if I join, I’ll lose precious time to make those last sales calls. My stomach twists as I hover between the meeting link and the phone, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding my full attention, each with consequences I can’t ignore.
